title: Mount Vesuvius
summary: Mount Vesuvius (/vɪˈsuːviəs/ viss-OO-vee-əs; Italian: Vesuvio[1] [veˈzuːvjo, -ˈsuː-]; Neapolitan: 'O Vesuvio[2] [o vəˈsuːvjə], also 'A muntagna or 'A montagna;[3] Latin: Vesuvius[4] [wɛˈsʊwɪ.ʊs], also Vesevius, Vesvius or Vesbius[5]) is a somma-stratovolcano located on the Gulf of Naples in Campania, Italy, about 9 km (5.6 mi) east of Naples and a short distance from the shore. It is one of several volcanoes which form the Campanian volcanic arc. Vesuvius consists of a large cone partially encircled by the steep rim of a summit caldera, caused by the collapse of an earlier and originally much higher structure.
